content: Maybe consider rewriting the statement. As is, it gives off strong 'All men are weirdo stalkers' vibes Maybe its true, but its not necessary to have that statement here.
Edited to fix the stub (string(x/z) ~> string (20)).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Seems to be a fun CoC :) I have coded myself the solution and it fits the idea behind CoC. The only caveat I would put on is related to the output messages which are less explicit for reverse mode, so we may struggle a bit trying to understand the logic behing 'weirdo stalker' messages.
I was approving the CoC, but there is an exception rised in "clojure" default code, needs to be fixed before an approval :)

The example makes it clear that (brackets), spaces and -dashes- are basically to be ignored, but I think it would be best if you explicitly mentioned this in the Input section.

e.g. "Next x lines: Numbers on woman's phone. (formatted as (###) ###-####)"

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think that this fits perfectly with CoC. My only thought is that for reverse mode, the outputs could maybe be a little more clear, for example, ("Known Contact!" and "Weirdo Stalker!") or ("Known Weirdo Stalker!" and "Unknown Weirdo Stalker!") or ("You Know This Weirdo Stalker!" and "You Don't Know This Weirdo Stalker!") Nothing too major and can still be figured out as is, however, I personally find it a little odd the way it is phrased.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Fun idea, however, this is a little too simple for clash of code. It's just manipulating lists.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: At start i was not sure if i will aprove or reject this one only because it is too complicated for CoC, you can make this a puzzle and maybe you will have a better rating, keep doing :)

...and removing formatting in order to correctly compare the two llists.

It's plenty complex for a "Fastest" mode Clash. I'd expect it would take at least 3-5 minutes for even skilled clashers.

There's been plenty of times when the default code in a CoC makes little sense for C++, and I end up having to redo it. There's not much I can do since I've never coded in Clojure and the stub used is the most logical for most programming languages :(
Fair enough, each to their own.  I guess I've been doing too much clash lately...
